snippet: Miss Williams made her debut at the New York City Opera in 1946 to rave notices. She was the first black woman to secure a contract with a major United States opera company.
abstract: Camilla Williams, pioneering soprano who was the first black woman to secure a contract with a major United States opera company, dies at age 92; Williams had never appeared in an opera when she took the lead role in the New York City Opera's first production of Puccini's Madama Butterfly in 1946, garnering rave notices; that Williams’s historic role is scarcely remembered today is rooted in both the rarefied world of opera-house politics and the ubiquitous racial anxiety of midcentury America.
lead_paragraph: Miss Williams made her debut at the New York City Opera in 1946 to rave notices. She was the first black woman to secure a contract with a major United States opera company.

headline.seo: Camilla Williams, a Lyric Soprano, Is Dead at 92
headline.main: Camilla Williams, Barrier-Breaking Opera Star, Dies at 92
headline.print_headline: Camilla Williams, Soprano, Dies at 92; Achieved Oft-Overlooked Breakthrough
